article.title: Investigacin innovadora para la produccin sostenible de fertilizantes y la gestin de nutrientes
article.teaser: Los fertilizantes desempean un papel esencial en la seguridad alimentaria. Su produccin y coste depende sobre todo de la disponibilidad de gas natural y, tras la invasin de Ucrania por parte de Rusia, el mundo afronta una crisis de fertilizantes que est suponiendo el encarecimiento de los alimentos. En este Results Pack sobre fertilizantes se presentan trece proyectos de investigacin financiados con fondos europeos que pueden ayudar a aliviar las presiones que sufren agricultores y consumidores a travs de la sntesis, el uso y la recuperacin de fertilizantes y la mejora de la gestin de nutrientes.

section.sectionBody:
Los seres humanos llevan ms de diez mil aos practicando la agricultura, que experiment una revolucin hace un siglo a travs del desarrollo de los fertilizantes qumicos sintticos. Hoy da, estos insumos transformadores estn amenazados, lo que demanda una nueva revolucin agrcola.
En noviembre de 2022, la Comisin Europea present la https://agriculture.ec.europa.eu/common-agricultural-policy/agri-food-supply-chain/ensuring-availability-and-affordability-fertilisers_es (Comunicacin Garantizar la disponibilidad y asequibilidad de los fertilizantes), que destacaba la necesidad de fortalecer la resiliencia y la sostenibilidad globales de nuestros sistemas alimentarios.
La investigacin e innovacin llevadas a cabo en el marco de Horizonte 2020 y su sucesor, Horizonte Europa, constituyen factores clave para reducir la dependencia de las importaciones de fertilizantes, mejorar la eficiencia del uso de fertilizantes y limitar la prdida de nutrientes para as garantizar la fertilidad del suelo y la asequibilidad de los alimentos.
Al crear suelos sanos ricos en materia orgnico y biodiversidad, optimizar la eficiencia del uso de fertilizantes y mejorar la recuperacin de nutrientes de flujos secundarios ricos en nutrientes, como el estircol, los residuos alimentarios o los lodos de depuradora, los agricultores europeos pueden producir cultivos ms sanos y con mayor rendimiento, al tiempo que reducen sus efectos y aumentan la resiliencia frente al cambio climtico.
Adems, la integracin de prcticas agrcolas y ganaderas, los mtodos de produccin de fertilizantes ms respetuosos con el medio ambiente (incluido el uso de hidrgeno verde), la diversificacin de cultivos y las variedades de plantas agroecolgicas estn contribuyendo a reducir la dependencia de la Unin Europea (UE) de los abonos minerales y los fertilizantes producidos con combustibles fsiles. Las soluciones basadas en el mercado tambin son fundamentales para lograr un sistema agrcola ms sostenible, como el https://eur-lex.europa.eu/eli/reg/2019/1009/oj?locale=es (Reglamento europeo sobre productos fertilizantes) de 2019, que introdujo un mercado nico de abonos orgnicos que facilita el comercio entre los Estados miembro de la UE.

section.sectionTitle: Una Europa ms limpia y respetuosa con el medio ambiente
section.sectionBody:
Sin embargo, la mejora de la gestin de nutrientes supone algo ms que defender nuestro sistema agrcola. En consonancia con el https://commission.europa.eu/strategy-and-policy/priorities-2019-2024/european-green-deal_es (Pacto Verde Europeo), la https://agriculture.ec.europa.eu/common-agricultural-policy/cap-overview/cap-2023-27_es (nueva poltica agrcola comn) incluye actividades para reducir las emisiones procedentes del uso de fertilizantes como parte de la accin general contra el cambio climtico. La reduccin del uso de fertilizantes tambin est relacionada con la https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/es/ip_22_1963 (Comunicacin para garantizar la seguridad alimentaria), adoptada en marzo de 2022, la https://food.ec.europa.eu/horizontal-topics/farm-fork-strategy_es (Estrategia De la Granja a la Mesa), el plan https://ec.europa.eu/commission/presscorner/detail/es/IP_22_3131 (REPowerEU) para lograr la independencia energtica y los objetivos del Plan de Accin europeo https://environment.ec.europa.eu/strategy/zero-pollution-action-plan_es (Contaminacin cero para el aire, el agua y el suelo).
La investigacin y la innovacin para la transicin hacia suelos sanos y una gestin sostenible del suelo cuentan con el apoyo de la misin de la UE https://rea.ec.europa.eu/funding-and-grants/eu-mission-soil-deal-europe_es (Un pacto sobre el suelo para Europa). La https://ec.europa.eu/eip/agriculture/en/european-innovation-partnership-agricultural (Asociacin Europea para la Innovacin en materia de Productividad y Sostenibilidad Agrcolas) (AEI-AGRI) fomenta la innovacin, el intercambio de conocimientos, la educacin y la formacin a fin de garantizar la resiliencia y la competitividad de las explotaciones agrarias.
La investigacin y la innovacin financiada con fondos europeos estn acelerando la transicin de Europa hacia sistemas agrcolas sostenibles, resilientes, circulares y competitivos.
Los trece proyectos que se presentan en este Results Pack sobre fertilizantes abarcan diferentes planteamientos. En varios de ellos, por ejemplo enhttps://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/443163/es (Sustainable Manure) y su sucesor https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/443161/es (SmartNitroFarm), as como enhttps://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/443164/es (Treat2ReUse), se estudia cmo se puede reciclar eficazmente el estircol como un fertilizante. En otros se examina cmo producir fertilizantes a partir de fuentes alternativas, como digestatos en https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/443157/es (NOMAD), bacterias mineras en https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/443153/es (BioRevolution), algas en https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/443155/es (Cyanobacteria) y aguas residuales de mataderos en https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/442075/es (Water2REturn) o de explotaciones en https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/443159/es (PSust-MOF). La necesidad de comprender y gestionar los ciclos de los nutrientes y la salud del suelo se aborda en https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/443160/es (SENSOILS), https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/443154/es (Circular Agronomics), https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/443158/es (Nutri2Cycle) y https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/443156/es (NitroFixSal), mientras que en https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/443162/es (SolACE) se investigan nuevas variedades de cultivos.

article.basedOn: Basado en informacin de los proyectos

article.title: Un nuevo tratamiento para reciclar mejor el estircol animal
article.teaser: La agricultura industrializada genera grandes cantidades de estircol animal concentrado y perjudicial para el medio ambiente. En un nuevo proyecto se ha ideado una forma de convertirlo en un mejor fertilizante y en una fuente de energa.

article.title: Expanding science education beyond school walls
article.teaser: By linking communities and schools, a European project envisions impactful learning experiences beyond traditional classrooms.

section.sectionBody:
Open schooling constitutes a diverse educational approach that extends learning opportunities beyond traditional classrooms, transcending barriers of time and access. This open approach not only fosters scientific literacy among students but also encourages them to pursue careers in science.
Despite the support from national and local educational authorities, a cohesive connection between schools, communities, museums and workplaces is currently lacking. Bridging this gap demands coordinated international efforts over time, reflecting the notion of opening schools to society.

section.sectionTitle: Engaging students with the wider community
section.sectionBody:
The EU-funded SALL project aims to advance open schooling by fostering collaboration in science education, envisioning schools as living labs integrated within society. The goal is to encourage schools to cooperate with stakeholders and create new partnerships in local communities, enhancing overall wellbeing.
SALL builds upon the foundation laid by the https://cordis.europa.eu/article/id/421969-open-schools-initiative-pushes-for-inclusive-and-innovative-societies (OSOS) project, the influential EU-funded project that pioneered the concept of open schooling. OSOS demonstrated how involving local communities in the teaching and learning process can drive inclusive and innovative societies. This involvement allows students to obtain a better understanding of global and local challenges as well as the relevance of science and technology in addressing them.
The ultimate goal is to enhance students' problem-solving and collaboration competencies, making science education more relevant and inclusive, states project coordinator Pavlos Koulouris.
At Makrygialos Primary School, Greece, students engaged in a living- lab school project on mussel farming, accompanying farmers on a boat out to sea and witnessing firsthand the impact of climate change on the local environment. This experience highlighted how such farming can sustain ecosystems and supports livelihoods, emphasising the critical link between the environment and community welfare.

The SALL team co-created the living lab methodology as a technique for the development of open schooling activities linked to science learning in Europes schools. Hundreds of teachers and schools across Europe enthusiastically adapted the methodology to suit their own needs and circumstances, generating inspiring school projects.
SALL living-lab projects revolve around real-life problems drawn from students experiences, working closely together with societal actors from the local community. Initially focused on food topics, these activities progressively expanded to all thematic areas, including green and digital issues.
The portfolio of SALL projects offers rich inspiration for those embarking on their own open schooling journey. It showcases examples from projects that have been implemented in schools across Europe, ranging from school gardens and promoting greener local food production, to analysing https://www.schoolofthefuture.eu/sites/default/files/2023-06/SALL%20Inspiring%20Projects4.pdf (eating behaviour), https://www.schoolofthefuture.eu/sites/default/files/2023-06/SALL%20Inspiring%20Projects7.pdf (composting food waste) and https://www.schoolofthefuture.eu/sites/default/files/2023-06/SALL%20Inspiring%20Projects17.pdf (protecting wildlife).

SALLs https://www.schoolofthefuture.eu/sall (community platform) welcomes everyone who wants to find, share and interact with school-based living lab activities. By applying SALLs living lab-based educational methodology, school communities can seamlessly integrate the open schooling approach into their daily practice, incorporating project-based, experiential learning into their curricula.
Evidence from participating schools suggests that the living-lab-based open schooling approach can have a positive impact on students self-esteem and civic engagement. Policy briefs ensure that such open schooling projects will find their way in Europes schools.
Initiatives like OSOS and SALL make science teaching a shared responsibility among leaders, teachers, students and the community, fostering responsible citizenship in European schools, emphasises Sofoklis Sotiriou, head of Research and Development at Ellinogermaniki Agogi.

article.keywords: SALL, open schooling, science education, local community, experiential learning, living lab, school projects

article.title: Paving the way for innovative educational contexts in the EU
article.teaser: If one thing is certain in our rapidly changing world, it is that transformation now takes place on a much deeper level, considering all the new branches of activity that are created every day. The challenge of keeping pace with all these changes is particularly acute for the education sector. The nine EU-funded projects featured in this Results Pack focus on fostering an open learning educational ecosystem that will equip students with all they need to navigate their life today and anticipate future advances.

article.title: Asset management for nature-based city flood resilience
article.teaser: Storm water poses a threat to cities through flooding, but also offers benefits for biodiversity and drinking water supplies. To tap it, Mind4Stormwater matched water management needs with real-time monitoring innovations, to enhance nature-based solutions.

section.sectionBody:
When flooding is caused by storm water it often reflects drainage infrastructure designed to fight nature, rather than work with it.
Recently there has been a shift from flood controls based on costly and maintenance-intensive grey (constructed) drainage networks, to hybrid systems incorporating nature-based solutions. These not only restore permeability to cities by managing rain at source reducing flood risk while increasing groundwater availability but also benefit the environment.
Popular assets include rain gardens, street swales or tree pits. Each solutions variety of shape and composition makes it readily adapted to local contexts.
But the advantage of these nature-based solutions their diversity and adaptability often proves their weakness, as they require tailor-made management, says research fellow Frdric Cherqui from the https://ec.europa.eu/research/mariecurieactions/ (Marie Skodowska-Curie Actions) supported project https://mind4stormwater.org/ (Mind4Stormwater). And as these assets are still young, mostly under 30 years old, their long-term performance and requirements are relatively unknown.
Mind4Stormwater adapted recent low-cost, connected and open-source monitoring systems to water infrastructure, to help build market trust in these solutions, while generating knowledge about their long-term performance.

While the scientific evidence is compelling for the benefits accrued from complementing grey (piped) infrastructure with nature-based solutions, trust must first be built in these solutions before widespread adoption, especially by city authorities.
Hybrid solutions need https://mind4stormwater.files.wordpress.com/2020/02/conf_lesam2019-cherqui-al_article.pdf (different management approaches). They are more discontinuous and widespread than grey infrastructure, and can be multifunctional, requiring competencies in both civil engineering and ecosystem science, adds Cherqui from https://www.univ-lyon1.fr/en (Lyon 1 University), the project host.
Monitoring infrastructure has traditionally been labour-intensive and expensive, but recent technological advances driven by falling costs, miniaturisation, ease-of-access, modularity and open-source programming offer real-time data gathering solutions.
Mind4Stormwater demonstrated the whole monitoring chain; from sensor development and installation, to data visualisation and real-time alerts.
After lab testing, the team designed and installed monitoring systems in partnership with http://mind4stormwater.online/ (Melbourne Water in Australia) and http://mind4stormwater.online/opendataeau/see/ (Greater Lyon in France).
Deployment included highly urbanised areas (such as Melbourne and Lyon) and a remote location (Officer, Australia), covering a range of solutions including wetland, green roof and stream.
Online platforms for the Australian and French pilots gathered sensor information, such as water levels, water turbidity, rain quantity and environmental features such as air temperature and humidity, supplying direct and indirect performance data.
Users could visualise or download the data in near real time every 5 to 30 minutes, depending on configuration. Alerts were set up for unexpected situations, related to the solution or the monitoring system itself.

Mind4Stormwater contributes directly to the https://ec.europa.eu/info/strategy/priorities-2019-2024/european-green-deal_en (EU Green Deal) aspiration of making cities more sustainable.
It is a business opportunity, offering green jobs for monitoring system manufacturers, installers and managers, not to mention the market in data, notes Cherqui.
As these assets are often outside, it is an opportunity to engage citizens, with free and easy access to monitoring data a first step to raising awareness about water management. Mind4Stormwaters knowledge, data and material is open-source and widely available.
The team continue to assess the benefits of these drainage solutions which will require years of additional testing. While doing so they will capitalise on constantly evolving communication, sensing and big data innovations. Additionally, the environmental impact of the monitoring system itself will be evaluated, including the possibility of integrating organic electronics.
Building on the results of Mind4Stormwater, the EU-funded https://co-udlabs.eu/ (Co-UDlabs) project is now also advancing knowledge and innovation for urban drainage systems.

article.keywords: Mind4Stormwater, flooding, resilience, drainage, nature-based, grey infrastructure, monitoring, Green Deal, water levels, rain, cities

article.title: Friendly fungus can protect crops and us from toxic mould
article.teaser: A novel treatment promises to slow the growth of microbes that spoil food crops and poison millions worldwide.

section.sectionBody:
Every year, https://www.wageningenacademic.com/doi/pdf/10.3920/WMJ2014.1737 (hundreds of millions of euros worth) of cereal crops are lost to fungal spoilage globally. Of particular concern are fungal species which produce http://programs.ifpri.org/afla/pdf/aflacontrol_wp04.pdf (compounds toxic to human health). http://ideagro.es/en/freemyco-un-innovador-metodo-de-bio-control-para-eliminar-la-contaminacion-por-micotoxinas-en-el-sector-agroindustrial/ (FREEMYCO) is a novel approach to combatting this issue using biological control.
We are trying to develop a new system, a bio-fungicide, explains project coordinator Alexia Stellfeldt, a non-toxic fungus that outcompetes pathogenic fungi.
Fungi are a ubiquitous presence in the soil, and can https://ec.europa.eu/jrc/en/eurl/mycotoxins (contaminate a wide range of crops) pre- and post-harvest. Some fungi, such as Aspergillus and Fusarium species, produce mycotoxins that cause sickness in humans and animals.
Whats more, animals fed contaminated grain can pass these mycotoxins to their meat, eggs and dairy products. We had huge contamination in milk here in Spain last year, says Stellfeldt. Eating food contaminated with mycotoxins can lead to kidney and liver damage, immune system deficiencies, and cancer.
Stellfeldt is project manager at http://ideagro.es/en/ (Ideagro), an independent company focused on agri-food research and development. Researchers there identified a strain of Trichoderma koningiopsis fungus that limits the growth of mycotoxin-producing species in the soil.
T. koningiopsis is itself a soil-dwelling species of fungi, so a single application can give protection for the entire season. The bio-control can be added to the soil before or after the crop is planted, with a kilogram of agent enough to treat one hectare of farmland.
Ideagro was granted funding from the EU to investigate the potential of T. koningiopsis as a bio-treatment for cereal crops, and the viability of the product in a global fungicide market that is worth around EUR 16 billion a year. Stellfeldt notes this would have been impossible to do without the EUs support: Due to the uncertainty of this kind of project, banks wont lend you the money for it.
The company now plans to carry out FREEMYCO field tests to further demonstrate its efficacy in a real-world setting. The team must also develop ways to mass-produce the bio-control. You can do some research in your laboratory with 10 millilitres of fungus, but when you reach the commercial stage, you need to adapt the conditions to produce the fungi on a huge scale, adds Stellfeldt.
Growing demand for food and shrinking resources particularly soil degradation means that agricultural land is under increasing pressure. Warm, wet conditions are conducive to fungal growth, and climate change is expected to https://ec.europa.eu/knowledge4policy/sites/know4pol/files/mycotoxin_brief_update_05-2020.pdf (aggravate the risk and severity of fungal outbreaks). Stellfeldt says the future of farming lies in developing novel agricultural products that work in harmony with the environment.
If successful, FREEMYCO will be the first effective and sustainable solution for controlling Aspergillus, compatible with conventional and organic farming. We need to find the tools to be more efficient, and have a more eco-friendly system, concludes Stellfeldt. To sum up, we need to do more with less.

article.keywords: FREEMYCO, fungus, fungi, fungicide, cereal, mycotoxin, grain, crop
